The under-representation of African American, Hispanic/Latino, and Native American students in U.S. universities continues to be an important impediment to the goal of a more equitable society. At the graduate level, under-representation among minority groups is even more striking than at the undergraduate level; for example, African Americans comprised fewer than nine percent of graduate school enrollments and Hispanics comprised just five percent of graduate school enrollments in the early 21st Century in U.S. universities. Under-representation may even be more important in California and Texas, which are the two largest states in the country in terms of population and also two of the most racially and ethnically diverse states. Indeed, both California and Texas are now considered to be "majority-minority" population states.

This collaborative renewal project -- which includes proposals from the University of Texas at Austin, Stanford University, Texas A&M University, and the University of Southern California -- will continue to address the under representation of Hispanics, African Americans, and Native Americans in graduate programs in the Social, Behavioral, and Economic (SBE) sciences at these four institutions. The project will continue to increase the enrollment, retention, and successful completion of under-represented minority (URM) graduate students in the SBE Sciences at alliance institutions, with the long-term intent to increase representation among URM groups on university faculties in the SBE sciences. Two principles continue to guide efforts. Alliance partners will: 1) share ideas, best practices, and resources, and create a network to recruit and retain students for alliance universities; and 2) build on successful initiatives that have already been developed on each of the campuses so that efforts can be as cost-effective and successful as possible. Highly collaborative and innovative methods will be used to improve efforts in recruiting and retaining minority graduate students at the institutions.

Broader Impact

The broader impact of this program is to influence the future of higher education in both
California and Texas. The future of higher education in these two critical majority-minority states in part depends on the ability of universities in these states to diversify the racial/ethnic mix of faculty. The collaborative effort presents one model of how to do so within the SBE sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT: At the University of Southern California (USC), Dr. Richard Andalon, Associate Dean and Director, with the support of university academic administrators, faculty, and professional staff, successfully designed and implemented the Enhancing Diversity in Graduate Education (EDGE) Program over a five-year period, which included a focus on the Social, Behavioral, and Economic (SBE) Science academic departments.  This project serves students directly and is an academic and professional development initiative, as well as a mentorship and scholarship/fellowship-awarding program. The project contributed to the development of Year-round and Summer Academic and Professional Development Institutes, Research and Professional Conference Travel Grant Program, Professionalization and Community Building Seminar Series, Fall Prospective Ph.D. Student  Visitation  and Recruitment Program, Supplemental Scholarships/Fellowship Awards, & variety of undergraduate & graduate student diversity outreach programs. In addition to using NSF grant funding, major financial and programmatic support for the project was also secured from the university through: matching funds, identifying students, facilitating mentorship experiences, and faculty and staff direct input and substantive involvement.   Currently, the project has the support of twelve USC SBE Sciences departments, including Anthropology, Marshall School of Business, Annenberg School for Communication, Economics, Geography, Davis School of Gerontology, Linguistics, School of Policy/Planning/ Development, Political Science, Psychology, Sociology, and American Studies and Ethnicity. Other departments such as History, English, and the School of Education have some students and faculty that have also become involved in the program. Some selected students and faculty from these departments have become involved because they are engaged in social sciences research and employing social sciences methodologies. Importantly, the School of Education has been supportive of project efforts, namely by assisting with career development  workshops, such CV/Resume Writing and teaching tips and strategies for interviews for fellowship and faculty positions. Furthermore, four administrative units have provided support for the program. First, the USC Graduate School, where the program is housed, provides full-time and part-time staffing, office space and equipment, and leverage to interface with students, faculty, and staff across the university. Second, the USC College of Letters, Arts, & Sciences Deans Office, the academic area where the majority of students come from, provides matching funds for stipends and encourages faculty and deans to participate in program operations. Third, the Office for the Protection of Human Research Subjects/Institutional Review Board provides essential overviews and training related to research protocols and research ethics. Fourth, the Center for Excellence in Teaching collaborates with the program by offering special workshops on teaching assistant training, teaching strategies, and professional career development.  At USC, we feel and have observed that our services, programs, and strategies are contributing immensely to the development of diversity outreach programs at the university, and most importantly, providing effective models of new ways to promote underrepresented  students' opportunities, learning, resources, and overall development. The project has helped foster a community of SBE Sciences scholars that includes faculty members and Ph.D. students from underrepresented backgrounds.
